awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Novel hydrogels for chronic diseases in pets and livestock
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact potential of this I-Corps project is a novel approach for the treatment of oral inflammatory and ulcerative diseases in dogs and cats. As the biggest challenge with inflammatory dental disease treatment lies in biofilm reduction, anti-viral mechanisms, immune system modulation, and reduction of inflammation, our solution tackles it all with economically feasible, easy to use, and efficient technology. This innovation will stimulate stem cells to grow and promote wound healing of damaged tissue by maintaining gingival mesenchymal stem cells homeostasis. This novel approach for Feline chronic gingivostomatitis treatment with the application of Lactic Acid Bacteria-derived metabolites and exosomes combined with organic zinc nanoparticles and hydrogel in a formulation.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of treatment of periodontal disease, which is the most common infectious condition in adult dogs and cats. It is a progressive, cyclical inflammatory disease of the supporting structures of the tooth and is the main cause of dental disease and early tooth loss in both species. It affects over 87% of dogs and 70% of cats over three years of age. This novel approach uses a hydrogel enriched with paraprobiotics (non-infectious microbial cell components such as peptidoglycans, teichoic acids, surface proteins, etc.) and lactic acid bacteria probiotics derived biomolecules, so-called postbiotics (exosomes, enzymes, secreted proteins, short chain fatty acids, vitamins, secreted biosurfactants, amino acids, peptides, organic acids, etc.) enhanced with biologically produced zinc oxide nanoparticles. This technology will help cats by reducing inflammation, dental plaque, chronic pain, promoting tissue and cell regeneration, treating viral infection, and improving wound healing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Our research project, titled "Novel Hydrogels for Chronic Diseases in Pets," focused on creating innovative solutions for chronic conditions in animals through advanced hydrogel formulations. This project aimed to improve the management of chronic diseases in pets by delivering targeted therapies through hydrogels that support healing and enhance overall pet health.

Intellectual Merit

The primary outcome of this project was the development of a specialized hydrogel designed for pets suffering from chronic diseases such as skin lesions, joint issues, and dental problems. Our team applied cutting-edge biotechnology to create a hydrogel that acts as a carrier for bioactive compounds, offering anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and regenerative properties.

One of the most significant steps in this project involved conducting over 200 interviews with medical professionals, including doctors and veterinarians, to ensure that our product was aligned with real-world needs. These extensive discussions allowed us to perform a thorough market fit analysis, which provided us with critical insights into how our solution could best meet the demands of both veterinarians and pet owners.

As a result of these interviews, our initial hydrogel formulation was refined and optimized based on expert feedback. This iterative process was key to ensuring that our final product was both scientifically sound and practically applicable in veterinary medicine. The modified solution demonstrated improved efficacy in chronic disease management for pets, incorporating the needs expressed by veterinarians in the field.

Broader Impacts

Our project contributes to the broader field of pet healthcare by introducing a novel solution for the treatment of chronic conditions. Chronic diseases in pets often require long-term care, which can be challenging for both veterinarians and pet owners. Our hydrogel offers a convenient and effective way to administer treatments, potentially reducing the burden on caretakers and improving the quality of life for pets.

The broader societal impact of this work also includes promoting better health outcomes for animals and supporting the veterinary community in adopting more advanced therapeutic options. The hydrogel solution could be further adapted for use in various species and chronic conditions, extending its benefits beyond pets to livestock and potentially even human medicine.

Conclusion

Through rigorous research and extensive consultation with over 200 experts, we developed a novel hydrogel solution for managing chronic diseases in pets. Our final product, refined based on real-world feedback, represents a significant advancement in veterinary care. This project not only contributed to the intellectual development of new therapeutic technologies but also addressed a critical market need, offering a solution that improves pet health and supports veterinarians in their practice.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2024
Modified by: Krzysztof M Marycz
